-MuJFhtbYBlxg8-NK-YQ.name: Unconditioned and Conditioned Reiforcers and Punishers

-MuJ7QCYaflRNFIOYoCm.definition: A stimulus that elicits (causes) a response without previous pairing with another stimulus.

-MuJ7QCcPdU1B3IaAsOY.definition: A response elicited (caused) by an unconditioned stimulus.

-MuJ7QCeRcbgkG9myyLy.definition: A stimulus that elicits (causes) a response because of previous pairing with another stimulus.

-MuJ7QE4CMJy1HuUxOmi.definition: A response elicited (caused) by a conditioned stimulus.

-MuJ7QE5oZJx0E5-aoO9.definition: Pairing a neutral stimulus with an unconditioned stimulus causes it to elicit the conditioned response.

-MuJ7QE7jnIuAh4YVrLZ.definition: Establishing a conditioned stimulus by pairing a neutral stimulus with an already established conditioned stimulus.

-MuJ7QE97ch9M77UwhR-.definition: Presenting the conditioned stimulus without pairing it with the unconditioned stimulus, or with an already established conditioned stimulus, and the conditioned stimulus will lose its eliciting power.

-MuJ7QEBAdlRZpIz3S4z.definition: Combining relaxation with a hierarchy of fear-­producing stimuli, arranged from the least to the most frightening.

-MuJ7QECAqVAadKJ8Af3.definition: A stimulus that increases the frequency of a response it follows.

-MuJ7QEENk5f_VoBcxyH.definition: The response-­contingent presentation of a reinforcer resulting in an increased frequency of that response.

-MuJ7QEFwoXuzSRpZsKi.definition: A stimulus that increases the future frequency of a response that its removal (termination) follows.

-MuJ7QEGdFoA0ZJNrVbm.definition: The response-contingent removal of a negative reinforcer resulting in an increased frequency of that response.

-MuJ7QEHyY7fxHMyIUk3.definition: A stimulus that decreases the future frequency of a response that its presentation follows.

-MuJ7QEI8noNtAtUHdXN.definition: The response-­contingent presentation of a punisher resulting in a decreased frequency of that response.

-MuJ7QEJM8Zl72c8SBsz.definition: Response-contingent removal of a reinforcer resulting in a decreased frequency of that response.

-MuJ7QEKMSIQuC81fZoz.definition: The occasion for a response, the response, and the outcome of the response.

-MuJ7QELo1LLuVLSuclr.definition: Stopping the positive or negative reinforcement contingency for a previously reinforced response causes the response frequency to decrease.

-MuJ7QEMbe_52DQYBs4N.definition: A description of a behavioral contingency.

-MuJ7QEN-2xessMobRd9.definition: Behavior under the control of a rule.

-MuJ7QEN-2xessMobRdA.definition: Behavior under the control of a direct-­acting contingency.

-MuJ7QFc2ufHnayudjNF.definition: A rule statement describing the desired or undesired behavior, the occasion when the behavior should or should not occur, and the added outcome for that behavior.
-MuJ7QFc2ufHnayudjNF.term: Contingency contract (behavioral contract or performance contract)

-MuJ7QFc2ufHnayudjNG.definition: The use of a contingency contract where the person whose behavior is being managed determines/ performs one or more components of that contract.

-MuJ7QFdkeXXK0H-wwil.definition: Reinforcing or pushing consequences immediately following a response increase or decrease it future frequency.

-MuJ7QFeFrOseTM6RGnJ.definition: Behavior that operates on the environment and is influenced by its reinforcing or punishing consequences.

-MuJ7QFeFrOseTM6RGnK.definition: The effects of our actions determine whether we will repeat them.

-MuJ7QFj_Wi8m76TnQq9.definition: The variable the experimenter systematically manipulates to influence the dependent variable.

-MuJ7QFmeDRbW_PB6BZL.definition: A measure of the participant’s behavior.

-MuJ7QFmeDRbW_PB6BZM.definition: The phase of an experiment or intervention where the behavior is measured in the absence of an intervention.

-MuJ7QFohy8tGQ760SVG.definition: An experimental design in which the replications involve baselines of differing durations and interventions of differing starting times.

-MuJ7QFohy8tGQ760SVH.definition: An explicit definition that makes it possible for two or more observers to identify the same behavior when it occurs.

-MuJ7QFpdGYR45tN1_4j.definition: Agreement between observations of two or more independent observers.

-MuJ7QFpdGYR45tN1_4k.definition: A group of participants exposed to the presumed crucial value of the independent variable.

-MuJ7QFq7_pL6G5w0J_0.definition: A group of participants not exposed to the presumed crucial value of the independent variable.

-MuJ7QFr-_PdKH03I_Zx.definition: Individuals serve as their own controls.

-MuJ7QFsisfcjpmfghuB.definition: A separate group of individuals serves as the control for the experimental group.

-MuJ7QHAZgJj2lFyGtY7.definition: The goals, procedures, and results of an intervention are socially acceptable to the client, the behavior analyst, and society.

-MuJ7QHB6LmE8cDYgOJ5.definition: The behavior being measured, the dependent variable.

-MuJ7QHCdOFqSEuCf82f.definition: Two or more independent variables have changed at the same time, so it is not possible to determine which of those variables caused the changes in the dependent variable.

-MuJ7QHDu9XA_3VGCi2d.definition: The addition or change of several independent variables at the same time to achieve a desired result, without testing the effects of each variable individually.

-MuJ7QHEHYtTzP4pkMuZ.definition: An experimental design in which we reverse the intervention and baseline conditions to assess the effects of those conditions.

-MuJ7QHEHYtTzP4pkMu_.definition: An experimental design in which the replications involve interventions with criteria of differing values.

-MuJ7QHFfEIYwfx6lFxs.definition: An experimental design in which the replications involve presenting different values of the independent variable in an alternating sequence under the same general conditions or in the same experimental phase, while measuring the same dependent variables.

-MuJ7QHGE2uABOt68hc7.definition: A condition not containing the presumed crucial value of the independent variable.

-MuJ7QHHX6Ishivl_myA.definition: The extent to which the conclusions of an experiment apply to a wide variety of conditions.

-MuJ7QHHX6Ishivl_myB.definition: The philosophy that the subject matter of psychology is the study of the effects of environmental variables on behavior, largely through experimental analysis.

-MuJ7QHI6V_9G7c2jLy7.definition: The philosophy that behaviorism should only deal with events that two or more scientists can observe.

-MuJ7QHJU1IVitMFKPf2.definition: The philosophy that behaviorism can consider many private events as behavior to which the principles of behavior apply.

-MuJ7QHJU1IVitMFKPf3.definition: The philosophy that the mind controls behavior.

-MuJ7QHLKFTkR45Kyi-9.definition: The source of cognitive skills or those cognitive skills themselves.

-MuJ7QHOUu3f48FIvq5u.definition: All events and all things have a cause.

-MuJ7QHPXcjpwTNtvEZN.definition: The use of no unnecessary concepts, principles, or assumptions.

-MuJ7QHQxHZ1o3pqPzOR.definition: The manipulation of events or conditions to evaluate their effects.

-MuJ7QInGSGjXVSAczKW.definition: Characteristics of species, behavior, and societies are selected by their consequences.

-MuJ7QIojw-3dl3kNa0n.definition: If a dead man can do it, it probably isn’t behavior.

-MuJ7QIp7lHFANS19OB6.definition: A muscular, glandular, or neuro-electrical activity.

-MuJ7QIp7lHFANS19OB7.definition: The study of the principles of behavior.

-MuJ7QIqhE54xHG-Foc4.definition: The use of experimental research to discover the effects of environmental variables on behavior, resulting in the basic principles of behavior.

-MuJ7QIrzvDg-BsjR55_.definition: The use of experimental research to discover ways to use the basic principles of behavior to solve socially significant problems.

-MuJ7QIrzvDg-BsjR55a.definition: The use of the basic and applied principles of behavior to solve socially significant problems.
-MuJ7QIrzvDg-BsjR55a.term: Professional practice guided by the science of behavior analysis

-MuJ7QIuf1AQeD2ETpj4.definition: To call an invented explanation a thing.

-MuJ7QIvZ7RXyKss8J-_.definition: An erroneous view that human problem behavior is a mere symptom of an underlying psychological condition.

-MuJ7QIw7NIBPabz8iCp.definition: Applied, behavioral, analytic, technological, conceptually systematic, effective, and general.
-MuJ7QIw7NIBPabz8iCp.term: Seven dimensions of applied behavior analysis

-MuJ7QIw7NIBPabz8iCq.definition: A stimulus that increases the future frequency of a response it follows

-MuJ7QIx1hDjU0dmqFLl.definition: Before spending much time trying to reinforce behavior, make sure you have a true reinforcer.

-MuJ7QIyIEZHm8_pQtAh.definition: The response itself automatically produces the reinforcer.

-MuJ7QIyIEZHm8_pQtAi.definition: Another person (or organism) provides the reinforcer.

-MuJ7QIzG8q9K1TKoUeq.definition: The occasion for a response, the response, and the outcome of the response.

-MuJ7QJ-m3NXyV5Cx9FI.definition: With nonverbal organisms, don’t say expects, knows, thinks, figures out, in order to (or so that he, she, or it could . . .), tries to, makes the connection, associates, learns that, imagines, or understands. With any organisms, don’t say wants.

-MuJ7QJ0VEflAu2G4l2R.definition: A stimulus that increases the future frequency of a response that its removal (termination) follows.

-MuJ7QJ2a-rgQjzMJCN0.definition: The response-contingent removal of a negative reinforcer resulting in an increased frequency of that response.

-MuJ7QJ4p5zdHwD3N2lp.definition: An assessment of the contingencies responsible for problem behaviors.

-MuJ7QKI5_1GyM2J_GN-.definition: In escaping the perpetrator’s aversive behavior, the victim unintentionally reinforces that aversive behavior.
-MuJ7QKI5_1GyM2J_GN-.term: Sick social cycle (victim’s negative reinforcement model)

-MuJ7QKJQty6RPSoVCFs.definition: A stimulus that decreases the future frequency of a response that its presentation follows.

-MuJ7QKMCCmstY0CR-hk.definition: The response-­contingent presentation of a punisher resulting in a decreased frequency of that response.

-MuJ7QKMCCmstY0CR-hl.definition: A contingency on inappropriate behavior requiring the person to engage in an effortful response that more than corrects the effects of the inappropriate behavior.

-MuJ7QKNmOoenr4r8HLF.definition: The perpetrator’s aversive behavior punishes the victim’s appropriate behavior, and the victim’s stopping the appropriate behavior unintentionally reinforces that aversive behavior.

-MuJ7QKO25KOJUUredM1.definition: Response-contingent removal of a reinforcer resulting in a decreased frequency of that response.

-MuJ7QKP-mcHViIagm3R.definition: The response-­contingent removal of a tangible reinforcer resulting in a decreased frequency of that response.

-MuJ7QKP-mcHViIagm3S.definition: The response-contingent removal of access to a reinforcer resulting in a decreased frequency of that response.

-MuJ7QKQ8HhXkKGn491-.definition: An experimental design in which we reverse the intervention and baseline conditions to assess the effects of those conditions.

-MuJ7QKQ8HhXkKGn4910.definition: Stopping the positive or negative reinforcement contingency for a previously reinforced response causes the response frequency to decrease

-MuJ7QKRfHRYhM2LaaiZ.definition: A temporary recovery of the extinguished behavior

-MuJ7QKSEkufVh60OQy1.definition: Stopping the positive or negative punishment contingency for a previously punished response causes the response frequency to increase to its frequency before the positive or negative punishment contingency.

-MuJ7QKT0FhaHHyJBfXy.definition: Consent to intervene in a way that is experimental or risky. The participant or guardian is informed of the risks and benefits and of the right to stop the intervention.

-MuJ7QKU0KbyIAu0bMSG.definition: An analysis of complex behavior and sequences of behavior into their component responses.

-MuJ7QKU0KbyIAu0bMSH.definition: Sometimes you need to make reinforcers and feedback contingent on the component responses of the process, not just the product (outcome).

-MuJ7QKVHdM81KLHyK4v.definition: The sequence (path of movement), form, or location of components of a response relative to the rest of the body.

-MuJ7QKWbMyY-TYTnKd_.definition: The time between the signal or opportunity for a response and the beginning of that response.

-MuJ7QKWbMyY-TYTnKda.definition: The time from the beginning to the end of a response.

-MuJ7QKXk-7d9Lc8DiSz.definition: The physical properties of a response.

-MuJ7QKY8gJFLreRspIf.definition: Reinforcement is contingent on a behavior that is incompatible with another behavior.

-MuJ7QKY8gJFLreRspIg.definition: A set of responses that serve the same function (produce the same outcome).

-MuJ7QKZFJ4G0EkMJLQS.definition: Reinforcing one set of responses and not reinforcing another set of responses.

-MuJ7QK_Ff62UiS29bLp.definition: Punishing one set of responses and not punishing another set of responses.

-MuJ7QK_Ff62UiS29bLq.definition: A reinforcer is presented after a fixed interval of time if the response of interest has not occurred during that interval.

-MuJ7QLtpfDnq4s-8yXE.definition: A stimulus that is a reinforcer, though not as a result of pairing with another reinforcer.

-MuJ7QLuEe1-gZpm8qFf.definition: A stimulus that is a punisher, though not as a result of pairing with another punisher.

-MuJ7QLvUzTkJ2KixKEn.definition: A stimulus that is a reinforcer because it has been paired with another reinforcer.

-MuJ7QLwmnCY1sPWJI8s.definition: The pairing of a neutral stimulus with a reinforcer or punisher.

-MuJ7QLwmnCY1sPWJI8t.definition: The pairing procedure converts a neutral stimulus into a conditioned reinforcer or conditioned punisher.

-MuJ7QLxVqaCkPcugmPi.definition: A conditioned reinforcer that is a reinforcer because it has been paired with a variety of other reinforcers.

-MuJ7QLyh73PzwgwMM4t.definition: A system of generalized conditioned reinforcers in which the organism that receives those generalized reinforcers can save them and exchange them for a variety of backup reinforcers later.

-MuJ7QLyh73PzwgwMM4u.definition: A stimulus that is a punisher because it has been paired with another punisher.

-MuJ7QLzl4NmlvVVS108.definition: Elements of a stimulus have their value or function only when they are combined; otherwise, the individual elements may be neutral.

-MuJ7QLzl4NmlvVVS109.definition: Withholding a reinforcer increases its effectiveness.

-MuJ7QM-xDaMfM_6e7kv.definition: Consuming a large amount of a reinforcer decreases its effectiveness.

-MuJ7QM0rfRYVX5rXP5Q.definition: An operation that affects the effectiveness of a reinforcer.

-MuJ7QM2GoMaPETMPapc.definition: An operation that increases the effectiveness of a reinforcer.

-MuJ7QM2GoMaPETMPapd.definition: An operation that decreases the effectiveness of a reinforcer.

-MuJ7QM3Ag0vjGSCkhVB.definition: Negative reinforcers and extinction are motivating operations for aggression reinforcers. Aggression reinforcer. A reinforcing stimulus resulting from acts of aggression.

-MuJ7QNRlM-OQqpZ7fBu.definition: A reinforcing stimulus resulting from acts of aggression.

-MuJ7QNUDcpxAqTbsaPx.definition: A reinforcer for which repeated exposure is a motivating operation.

-MuJ7QNXxNP21vIKvwFx.definition: A stimulus in the presence of which a particular response will be reinforced or punished.

-MuJ7QNXxNP21vIKvwFy.definition: A stimulus in the presence of which a particular response will not be reinforced or punished.

-MuJ7QNYkOS8Q4oW_XZw.definition: Reinforcing or punishing a response in the presence of one stimulus and extinguishing it or allowing it to recover in the presence of another stimulus.

-MuJ7QNZspZLxClOgQNo.definition: The occurrence of a response more frequently in the presence of one stimulus than in the presence of another, usually as a result of a discrimination training procedure.

-MuJ7QN_t0uWWCMwKXTX.definition: The planned use of behavioral contingencies, differential reinforcement, and discrimination training in the student’s everyday environment.

-MuJ7QNbT4e7WbyeToVv.definition: A supplemental stimulus that raises the probability of a correct response.

-MuJ7QNbT4e7WbyeToVw.definition: That part of the environment the organism operates (manipulates).

-MuJ7QNcg7yCNz8xRE8R.definition:
-S∆ Test
--Is there also an S∆? If not, you don't have an SD.

-Same before condition test
--Is the before condition the same for both SD & S∆?

-Response test
-- Is the response the same for SD & S∆?

-Extinction/recovery test
--Is the S∆  contingency always escape or recovery?

-Operandum test
--Does the SD differ from the operandum?

-Different before condition test
--Does the SD differ from the before condition?

-MuJ7QNd779GA2rF80-H.definition: Reinforcing or punishing a response in the presence of one stimulus class and extinguishing it or allowing it to recover in the presence of another stimulus class.

-MuJ7QNd779GA2rF80-I.definition: A set of stimuli, all of which have some common physical property.

-MuJ7QNeFOxExWH2toxj.definition: The behavioral contingencies in the presence of one stimulus affect the frequency of the response in the presence of another stimulus.

-MuJ7QNfjoxb137LSDI2.definition: Responding occurs more often in the presence of one stimulus class and less often in the presence of another stimulus class because of concept training.

-MuJ7QNg4iQKAH-6gkuL.definition: The physical properties of a stimulus.

-MuJ7QNg4iQKAH-6gkuM.definition: At first, the SD and S∆ differ along at least one irrelevant dimension, as well as the relevant dimensions. Then the difference between the SD and S∆ is reduced along all but the relevant dimensions, until the SD and S∆ differ along only those relevant dimensions.

-MuJ7QNheA-AHlUCWH_j.definition: The use of a fading procedure to establish a discrimination, with no errors during the training.

-MuJ7QNheA-AHlUCWH_k.definition: A gradient of responding showing an increase in stimulus control as the test stimulus becomes less similar to the training stimulus.

-MuJ7QNia6xctW728agI.definition: The criteria for measurement are not completely specified in physical terms or the event being measured is a private, inner experience.

-MuJ7QNjTSiSE8NZqaCf.definition: The criteria for measurement are completely specified in physical terms and the event being measured is public and therefore observable by more than one person.

-MuJ7QNkjv_UTUD6k1QC.definition: Selecting a comparison stimulus corresponding to a sample stimulus.

-MuJ7QOzS9S17diVx0yY.definition: The form of the behavior of the imitator is controlled by similar behavior of the model.

-MuJ7QP-4pAaEUHKOWTw.definition: The trainer physically moves the trainee’s body in an approximation of the desired response.

-MuJ7QP0z1ij7KLR_c8B.definition: Imitation of the response of a model without previous reinforcement of imitation of that specific response.

-MuJ7QP1U774XpVp9dTM.definition: A supplemental verbal stimulus that raises the probability of a correct response.

-MuJ7QP4suFIALkrP4cs.definition: Generalized imitative responses occur because they automatically produce imitative reinforcers.

-MuJ7QP5mnttj5lrCIcF.definition: Stimuli arising from the match between the behavior of the imitator and the behavior of the model that function as reinforcers.

-MuJ7QP6oUeCht99y4ZW.definition: Response-­contingent prevention of a negative reinforcer resulting in an increased frequency of that response.

-MuJ7QP7_3wAiuHPtvVY.definition: Response-­contingent prevention of loss of a reinforcer resulting in an increased frequency of that response.

-MuJ7QP7_3wAiuHPtvVZ.definition: A stimulus that precedes a negative reinforcer and therefore becomes a conditioned negative reinforcer.

-MuJ7QP9Ozb97lNPLK2c.definition: Behavior not in the repertoire or not occurring at the desired frequency; the goal of the intervention.

-MuJ7QPAH12ovfH-OcmK.definition: The frequency of responding before reinforcement.

-MuJ7QPAH12ovfH-OcmL.definition: Behavior that resembles the terminal behavior along some meaningful dimension and occurs at least with a minimal frequency.

-MuJ7QPBw0bzMx4Cd0TV.definition: Behavior that more closely approximates the terminal behavior.

-MuJ7QQYIj4q0Q2_-sOW.definition: The differential reinforcement of only the behavior that more and more closely resembles the terminal behavior.

-MuJ7QQZgM7RQ6-q3z8h.definition: The differential punishment of all behavior except that which more and more closely resembles the terminal behavior.

-MuJ7QQ_yGRCDKnEHsEP.definition: Shaping that involves no change in the value of the reinforcer, as performance more and more closely resembles the terminal behavior.

-MuJ7QQ_yGRCDKnEHsEQ.definition: Shaping that involves a change in the value of the reinforcer, as performance more and more closely resembles the terminal behavior.

-MuJ7QQaCTxV2CDZv6aH.definition: A sequence of stimuli and responses. Each response produces a stimulus that reinforces the preceding response and is an SD or operandum for the following response.

-MuJ7QQbLRjKuS51XMf4.definition: A stimulus in a behavioral chain reinforces the response that precedes it and is an SD or operandum for the following response.

-MuJ7QQbLRjKuS51XMf5.definition: The establishment of the first link in a behavioral chain, with the addition of successive links, until the final link is acquired.

-MuJ7QQcDQduzMQrkVl6.definition: The establishment of the final link in a behavioral chain, with the addition of preceding links until the first link is acquired.

-MuJ7QQdGCLJDpSunrrZ.definition: The simultaneous training of all links in a behavioral chain.

-MuJ7QQfX1sN_a0SIGlh.definition: Reinforcement schedule in which a reinforcer follows the response only once in a while.

-MuJ7QQhACWB2Gieu3vz.definition: The way reinforcement occurs because of the number of responses, time since reinforcement, time between responses, and stimulus conditions.

-MuJ7QQiJzewhHtVI8Xd.definition: A reinforcer is contingent on the last of a fixed number of responses.

-MuJ7QQiJzewhHtVI8Xe.definition: After a response is reinforced, no responding occurs for a period of time, then responding occurs at a high, steady rate until the next reinforcer is delivered.

-MuJ7QS7Nk1MWmPf9dkp.definition: A reinforcer is contingent on the last of a variable number of responses.

-MuJ7QS8md7yAEkTyGjV.definition: Variable-ratio schedules produce a high rate of responding, with almost no post-­ reinforcement pausing.

-MuJ7QS8md7yAEkTyGjW.definition: The variable the experimenter systematically manipulates to influence the dependent variable.

-MuJ7QS9AgZbqbqz39-s.definition: A measure of the subject's behavior

-MuJ7QSAe7IEoIOnZjCv.definition: A reinforcer is contingent on the first response after a fixed interval of time since the last opportunity for reinforcement.

-MuJ7QSAe7IEoIOnZjCw.definition: A fixed-­interval schedule often produces a scallop—a gradual increase in the rate of responding, with responding occurring at a high rate just before reinforcement is available. No responding occurs for some time after reinforcement.

-MuJ7QSBIkRtcx9JLhpD.definition: A reinforcer is delivered after the passage of a fixed period of time, independent of the response.

-MuJ7QSCTRwpKwreDJ3O.definition: Behaving as if the response causes some specific outcome, when it really does not.

-MuJ7QSDjc8DG6JZT9MG.definition: A reinforcer is contingent on the first response after a variable interval of time since the last opportunity for reinforcement.

-MuJ7QSE1BlvIy640aKT.definition: Variable-­interval schedules produce a moderate rate of responding, with almost no post-reinforcement pausing.

-MuJ7QSE1BlvIy640aKU.definition: The number of responses or the amount of time before a response extinguishes.

-MuJ7QSH4k1EcGq2ozZi.definition: Intermittent reinforcement makes the response more resistant to extinction than does continuous reinforcement.
-MuJ7QSH4k1EcGq2ozZi.term: Resistance to extinction and intermittent reinforcement

-MuJ7QSH4k1EcGq2ozZj.definition: More than one contingency of reinforcement or punishment is available at the same time.

-MuJ7QSIr33hOIG8FDUe.definition: Withholding reinforcement for an inappropriate response, while providing reinforcement for an appropriate response.

-MuJ7QSJbXrRuBZxHATy.definition: Problem behaviors are symptoms of an underlying mental illness. So if you get rid of one problem behavior (“symptom”), another will take its place, until you get rid of the underlying mental illness.

-MuJ7QSJbXrRuBZxHATz.definition: The addition or change of several independent variables at the same time to achieve a desired result, without testing the effect of each variable individually.

-MuJ7QSKhiQ8S5iHaC8v.definition: When two different responses are each reinforced with a different schedule of reinforcement, the relative frequency of the two responses equals the relative value of reinforcement on the two schedules of reinforcement.

-MuJ7QSLw1XlopQEMPkj.definition: The continuing of performance after it was first established.

-MuJ7QSLw1XlopQEMPkk.definition: Use an added reinforcement contingency to increase the rate of behavior. Then the behavior can be reinforced by natural reinforcement contingencies, and those natural contingencies can maintain that behavior.

-MuJ7QSMeMdmA9kRXNd7.definition: Performance established at one time in one place now occurs in a different time and place.

-MuJ7QSMeMdmA9kRXNd8.definition: Imitation of the vocal behavior of another speaker.

-MuJ7QSOWvx4Hf7LCSOf.definition: Behavior under the stimulus control of a speaker.

-MuJ7QSPwhIIoHkM-fCN.definition: Novel verbal behavior that has not been directly trained.

-MuJ7QSQk4Ypl3Kx7-0_.definition: Behavior reinforced through the mediation of other persons.

-MuJ7QTfuI5k1q8_AjCN.definition: A verbal operant that modifies the effect of other verbal operants.

-MuJ7QTgVoOCM8NfGvi_.definition: A verbal operant under the stimulus control of other verbal operants.

-MuJ7QThwO5zEuWgYAFL.definition: When one stimulus is an SD for a response, then the stimulus associated with that response is also an SD for a response to the first stimulus, without explicit training to establish that other stimulus as an SD.

-MuJ7QThwO5zEuWgYAFM.definition: When a stimulus is an SD for one response, then the stimulus associated with that response will be an SD for the response associated with the first stimulus.

-MuJ7QTiJxNLGq4jfrW-.definition: When one stimulus is the SD for two different responses, then the stimulus associated with one of those two responses will be an SD for the other of those two responses.

-MuJ7QTiJxNLGq4jfrW0.definition: The matching of two identical stimuli; A=A.

-MuJ7QTmvClLO3YzrEMx.definition: The training of stimuli using symbolic match to sample that produces stimulus equivalence.

-MuJ7QTp9a_Pl8V4ArsJ.definition: Stimuli are equivalent, when they have symmetrical, transitive, and reflexive relations but do not have common physical properties.

-MuJ7QTq5DKm3yDPFnJ3.definition: The relation between two or more stimuli is derived from independent training with those stimuli and other stimuli with which they have a relation.

-MuJ7QTrfJx5p-FayslZ.definition: A description of a behavioral contingency

-MuJ7QTs9Jjq4gkSQqQW.definition: Behavior under the control of a direct-acting contingency

-MuJ7QTs9Jjq4gkSQqQX.definition: Behavior under the control of a rule

-MuJ7QTtTaM9T5K5dxJQ.definition: A contingency in which the outcome of the response reinforces or punishes that response.

-MuJ7QTtTaM9T5K5dxJR.definition: A contingency that controls the response, though the outcome of the response does not reinforce or punish the response.

-MuJ7QTuKCCdBm0Z7bTg.definition: A contingency that does not control behavior.

-MuJ7QTuKCCdBm0Z7bTh.definition: A change in the frequency of a response because of a rule describing the contingency.

-MuJ7QTvcM02YAlav53J.definition: Sometimes you need to make reinforcers and feedback contingent on the component responses of the process, not just the product.

-MuJ7QVD0AzRE4ERDRkM.definition: An analysis of complex behavior and sequences of behavior into component responses

-MuJ7QVEOWfUEznpT7ms.definition: Nonverbal stimuli or verbal statements contingent on past behavior that can guide future behavior.

-MuJ7QVFFLU6aliGEykG.definition: Poor self-management occurs because immediate outcomes control our behavior better than delayed outcomes do.

-MuJ7QVFFLU6aliGEykH.definition: Describe outcomes that are both sizable and probable. The delay isn’t crucial.
-MuJ7QVFFLU6aliGEykH.term: Rules that are easy to follow

-MuJ7QVG46MwhYp2Bxqq.definition: Describe outcomes that are either too small (though often of cumulative significance) or too improbable.
-MuJ7QVG46MwhYp2Bxqq.term: Rules that are hard to follow

-MuJ7QVG46MwhYp2Bxqr.definition: Poor self-­management results from poor control by rules describing outcomes that are either too small (though often of cumulative significance) or too improbable. The delay isn’t crucial.

-MuJ7QVH6urcP7dtgFDp.definition: The three crucial contingencies are the ineffective natural contingency, the effective, indirect-acting performance-management contingency, and the effective, direct-acting contingency.

userInfo.where_to_send_results: I love POB save the world with behavior analysis
